text: hello everyone and welcome to today's webinar predicting costs with Amazon Web Services so today we're going to talk
about the the challenges of predicting costs with Amazon Web Services we receive a lot of questions about this
and we put together this webinar to help you do a better job of doing that that cost prediction so we'll kind of jump in
and we'll take a look at the the various challenges inherent in understanding and measuring the costs of of cloud-based
computing we'll talk about a set of principles and methodologies that I call
the 5ms we'll review some of the tools that are available to you to help do your your cost prediction we'll spend a
lot of time working through a number of costing examples and then we're gonna do as much live Q&A as possible given the
amount of time that we have available so what are some of the challenges that we
face as we move to cloud services the first big change that people notice is that the cloud model is pay-as-you-go so
the the actual cost model of the cloud is going to be directly related to the amount of services that you consume when
you design the architecture for your cloud based system you get to make a number of different trade-offs that will
basically control cost versus reliability the number of instances you have running the number of the amount of
redundancy you have across multiple availability zones and so forth we have
the challenge of automatic scaling where you can configure your application to scale up and scale down in response to
changing load or traffic we have the the real challenge of viral applications
where you put your application online and it can be quickly passed from person to person in in a situation that will
then force you to scale very very quickly as you build your application in
the cloud you can make use of a number of different cloud services and you can end up with a rather complex architecture with the number of
different cost components and cost drivers you might also find that some of the parts of the application turned out
to be rather expensive features and that they are relatively high consumers of resources relative to the value that
they provide when you build your application with the cloud you can often can build it and put it
online fairly rapidly so that the challenge of understanding your costs in that relatively short amount of time you
help to design build and deploy it is also present and we also have the challenge of continuous deployment you
conceive of new features you implement those you put those online and you don't always have time to do a complete and
thorough analysis of the the cost implications of those new features so
see these are some of the things that we hear from our customers as the challenges that they face on the other
side there's quite a number of new opportunities for you the first is that because the cloud is pay-as-you-go based
pricing you have the opportunity to have very detailed visibility into your costs the cloud is economical and it offers
you the opportunity to have dramatic cost savings and it also lets you price your application according to your car
so you can be very request aggressive with your your pricing once you understand complete understanding of
your actual costs one interesting thing you might want to think about is that when you do understand the cost at the
feature level we're going to talk about ways that you can actually measure that the cost at the feature level you can
consider having a premium charge for the features that are expensive for you to actually to operate this opens the door
to new business models and also something I've emphasized in my talks for several years is the fact that because we have a pay-as-you-go model
and because you can build a very scalable system you should be able to construct businesses that are going to be profitable at any scale because you
don't have what has traditionally been the the enemy of profitability at the very large fixed costs so here are some
questions I have for you and these are these are somewhat hypothetical questions and that I haven't yet met any
any business or entrepreneur that really knows these questions in detail but these are goals just drive for so I
